711574f-a.text:
135 to 159 East 21st Street, north side, east from but not including Lexington, to and including Third Aves., and showing a portion of the Third Ave. Evelevated Line. No. 147-151 (the 4-story building with protruding semicircular windows) is the Grace Girls Club.
July 7, 1928,
P. L. Sperr.

Slide #58
711574f-a.title: Manhattan: 21st Street (East) - Lexington

711575f-a.text:
21st Street west from No.117, adjoining the N.E. corner of Lexington Avenue, to Fourth Avenue. The Hotel Gramercy Park, a portion of which is seen in this picture, is on the N.W. corner of Lexington Avenue and 21st Street. The houses at 107-109 East 21st Street are being demolished to permit the erection of a 16-story apartment house.
October 12, 1929
P.L. Sperr.

720040f-a.folder: Gramercy Park North & Lexington Avenue, Manhattan, NY
720040f-a.text:
52 to 6l Gramercy Park North (where tall building are facing), at, adjoining and west of the N.W. corner of Lexington Ave., showing the three units (16, 6, and 16-stories) of the Gramercy Park Hotel (No. 52); a 16-story apartment house (No. 6O), and the 9-story Calvary Parish House (No. 61), as seen across Gramercy Park from Srving Place. In the foreground appears Gramercy Park South; on the left, low buildings on Gramercy Park West, and in the right background, a view north of Lexington Ave. from its starting point at Gramercy fark North. Note also (left background) the tower of the Metropolitan Life IInsurance Building. The name of Gramercy Park is said to be derived from Krom Moerasje (Crooked Little Swamp) formed by Cedar Creek, which formerly flowed from Madison Square to the East River. The present park once formed part of a large farm acquired in 1761 by dames Duane, once Mayor of New York City and by him christened "Gramercy Seat". It is an exclusive park, not open to the public; in the center of which appears a
statue of Edwin Booth in the role of Prince Hamlet.
About 1932.
Ewing Galloway.
SN ~ 72
720040f-a.title: Manhattan: Gramercy Park North - Lexington Avenue

720041f-a.folder: Gramercy Park North & Lexington Avenue, Manhattan, NY
720041f-a.text:
Gramercy Park North, south side, west from Lexington Ave., to Gramercy Park West (western boundary of fenced area). This thoroughfare when west of the latter point regains its original identity as East 21st Street and proceeds across Fourth Ave. At the S.E. corner of the latter two
points is the huge Rex Cole Building.
August 5, 1937.
P. L. Sperr.
720041f-a.title: Manhattan: Gramercy Park North - Lexington Avenue

720042f-a.folder: Gramercy Park North & Lexington Avenue, Manhattan, NY
720042f-a.text:
(1)
Gramercy Park North (buildings thereon) east from Lexington Ave., to and including Gramercy Park East (right background), and showing a full view of Gramercy Park in a northeasterly direction from Gramercy Park South, south side, between Irving Place and Fourth Ave.
July 7, 1928.
P. L. Sperr.
Slide #73

(2)
The same, but showing only the northeastern portion of the Park.
July 7, 1928.
P. L. Sperr.

720043f-a.folder: Gramercy Park North & Lexington Avenue, Manhattan, NY
720043f-a.text:
Gramercy Park North (where buildings are facing), north side, at Lexington Ave., showing (right to left) No. 1 Lexington Ave., at the N.E. corner of Gramerey Park North, the Hotel Gramercy Park, at the N.E. corner of Lexington Ave., consisting of two 16-story units separated by a 6-story one, and No. 60, 16-story apartment hotel, as seen across Gramercy Park from Gramercy Park South. On the left appears a portion
oof Gramercy Park West.
About 1932.
Ewing Galloway.
